I put a some detail [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/issues/19), but my concernse come down to the following. Just to be clear, since tone and inflection are not present in text, this is not meant to be a rebuke. Rather it’s an insight into how I’d like to handle software development and why.

1. Using Eigen is a major change, one that was not throughoughly discussed with project leaders, which may be just me, or factored into the roadmap. These types of changes will cause us to perpetually chase after the next best feature.
2. “Small tweaks” almost always escalate to major code refactors that affect the entire team. While making a change here or in ign-math may seem small, everyone else may have dedicate time to adopting and adjusting to these small tweaks. This is speculation, but has proven itself to be true very often.
3. While Eigen is definitely better than ign-math in some ways, no one beside developers \(mostly us\) will care. 
4. Different ignition libraries will now use different math libraries, and probably have different public APIs. This makes our libraries look poorly designed. We will also now transform between types, which may \(speculation again\), negatively impact performance.
5. Arguing for Eigen instead of ign-math because we’d have to change code in the future doesn’t carry a lot of weight with me. It is always true that we will have to change and refactor code in the future. A saying that I keep hearing more and more applies here: “Don’t let perfection get in the way of good”, or “Perfection is the enemy of done”.

Since we are now in this situation, we might as well go forward instead of debating the issue. Here is how I’d like to proceed:

1. Limit the amount of changes that downstream users, mostly other ignition library developers, will have to make. This may involve some kind of conversion between types.
2. Limit the use of Eigen in public APIs as much as possible.
3. If there is another major change, which can roughly be anything that effects multiple libraries/people, then make sure the relevant people are informed and have agreed.
